title: 115_hr1727
content: The Act titled "Limiting Inhumane Federal Trapping Act" prohibits the use of body-gripping traps by personnel and on lands of the Departments of the Interior and Agriculture. The Act prohibits the use of body-gripping traps by Department of the Interior and Department of Agriculture personnel and on their lands, with exceptions for controlling invasive species. The Act prohibits the use of body-gripping traps by Department of the Interior and Department of Agriculture personnel and on their lands, with exceptions for controlling invasive species or protecting endangered or sensitive species, subject to compliance with State and Federal laws. Before using a body-gripping trap, nonlethal methods must be attempted and documented in writing. The Act prohibits the use of body-gripping traps, except for specific situations such as controlling invasive species or protecting endangered species. Training in dismantling illegal traps and use in Indian country are also exempt. Penalties are imposed for knowing violations of the Act or regulations. The Act prohibits the use of body-gripping traps, with penalties for violations including fines and imprisonment. A body-gripping trap is defined as a device intended to kill or capture an animal by restraining it physically. The Act prohibits the use of certain traps, including padded, enclosed, and kill-type traps, as well as snare traps. It does not include cage or box traps. The term "Indian country" and "personnel" are also defined in the Act. The Act does not conflict with the Alaska National Interests Lands Conservation Act. It also does not preempt stricter state laws regarding wildlife trapping.
